sen.j: 唐菓子（とうがし）は、奈良時代に唐（中国）から伝来した一連の菓子とその技術を言う。
sen.e: Togashi refers to a series of cakes and its technology that were transmitted from To (China) in the Nara period.
Togashi refers to a series of cakes and the technique used to make them that were introduced from Tang (China) in the Nara period.
Togashi refers to a series of cakes and the technique used to make them that were introduced from Tang (China) in the Nara period.

sen.j: からくだものと呼ぶ事もある。
sen.e: It is sometimes called Karakudamono.
It is sometimes called Karakudamono.
It is sometimes called Karakudamono.

sen.j: 唐菓子が伝わる以前の日本には現在の意味での「菓子」は存在せず、菓子は果子とも書かれて果物を意味していた。
sen.e: In Japan before Togashi comes, there is no "cake" in a current meaning and cakes were written in "果子", which means fruit.
Before the arrival of Togashi, there were no "cakes" in the current sense of the meaning in Japan, and the word for cakes was written as "果子," which meant fruit.
sen.cmt: comes→came, is→was、means→meantに修正、カンマの位置を移動
sen.e: Before the arrival of Togashi, there were no "cakes" in the current sense of the meaning in Japan, and the word for cakes was written as "果子," which meant fruit.

sen.j: 唐菓子は小麦粉を用い胡麻油で揚げるなどの技法が用いられる。
sen.e: Technique is adopted for making Togashi to be made of wheat flour and be fried with sesame oil.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Technique is adopted for making Togashi to be made of wheat flour and be fried with sesame oil.
The technique used to make Togashi was to fry wheat flour-based dough in sesame oil.

sen.j: 日本に大きな影響を与え、和菓子のルーツの一つとなった。
sen.e: Togashi has given a significant impact to Japan, and has become one of the roots of a Japanese sweet.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Togashi has given a significant impact to Japan, and has become one of the roots of a Japanese sweet.
Togashi has given a significant impact to Japan, and has become one of the roots of a Japanese sweet.

sen.j: 貴族に愛好されたばかりでなく、神餞や仏前にも供えられた。
sen.e: Togashi was loved by nobles, and moreover offered to the gods or before the altar of temple.
Togashi was loved by nobles, and moreover offered to the gods or before the altar of temples.
Togashi was loved by nobles, and moreover offered to the gods or before the altar of temples.

sen.j: 平安時代には、『和名類聚抄』などで一部のものが特に八種唐菓子と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, some Togashi was particularly called eight kinds of Togashi such as in "Wamyo Ruijusho."
In the Heian period, some Togashi were particularly called the Eight Kinds of Togashi such as in the "Wamyo Ruijusho" (dictionary of Japanese names).
sen.cmt: was→were、the Eight Kinds of Togashi、in the "Wamyo Rijusho"とし、補足追加 (用語集参照)
sen.e: In the Heian period, some Togashi were particularly called the Eight Kinds of Togashi such as in the "Wamyo Ruijusho" (dictionary of Japanese names).

sen.j: しかし鎌倉時代末期には、その多くが既に忘れ去られていた。
sen.e: However, the most of them were already forgotten in the end Kamakura period.
However, the most of them were already forgotten at the end of the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: in the end Kamakura period→at the end of the Kamakura periodとしました。
sen.e: However, the most of them were already forgotten at the end of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 一方、煎餅など一部は形を変えて現在まで残っている。
sen.e: On the other hand, some of them such as rice crackers has been remained to date in a changed form.
On the other hand, some of them such as rice crackers have remained to date in a changed form.
On the other hand, some of them such as rice crackers have remained to date in a changed form.

sen.j: 現存しているものとしては、神社で製造されるぶとが代表的である。
sen.e: Among existing ones, "Buto" produced in shrines is representative.
Among existing ones, "Buto" produced in shrines is representative.
Among existing ones, "Buto" produced in shrines is representative.

sen.j: また、京都には「清浄歓喜団」(亀屋清永)と呼ばれるだんきが現存している。
sen.e: In addition, Danki referred to as "Seijokankidan" (Kameyakiyonaga) exists in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In addition, Danki referred to as 'Seijokankidan' (Kameyakiyonaga) exists in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: In addition, Danki referred to as 'Seijokankidan' (Kameyakiyonaga) exists in Kyoto.

sen.j: 寺院に奉納される他、和菓子として市販もされている。
sen.e: It is dedicated to temples, and put on the market as a Japanese sweet.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is dedicated to temples, and put on the market as a Japanese sweet.
It is dedicated to temples, and put on the market as a Japanese sweet.

sen.j: なお、饅頭、羊羹、ういろう (菓子)、落雁、月餅、一口香なども中国から渡来してきたものである。
sen.e: Here, such as manjyu, yokan, uiro (a cake), rakugan, geppei, ikkoko have been brought over from China.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Here, such as manju, yokan, uiro (a cake), rakugan, geppei, ikkoko have been brought over from China.
Here, such as manju, yokan, uiro (a cake), rakugan, geppei, ikkoko have been brought over from China.

sen.j: これらは鎌倉時代以降に渡来したため、普通は唐菓子には含めない。
sen.e: Because these have been brought over after the Kamakura period, these are not usually included in Togashi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Because these have been brought over after the Kamakura period, these are not usually included in Togashi.
Because these have been brought over after the Kamakura period, these are not usually included in Togashi.

tit.cmt: The追加、頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 梅枝（ばいし）
sen.e: Baishi
Baishi
Baishi

sen.j: 米の粉を水で練り、ゆでてウメの枝のように成形し、油で揚げたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading a powder of rice with water and boiling it to mold into a plum branch shape, and then frying it in oil.
It is made by kneading rice flour with water and boiling it to mold into a plum branch shape, and then frying it in oil.
sen.cmt: a powder of rice→rice flourとしました。
sen.e: It is made by kneading rice flour with water and boiling it to mold into a plum branch shape, and then frying it in oil.

sen.j: 桃枝（とうし）
sen.e: Toshi
Toshi
Toshi

sen.j: 梅枝と同様に作り、モモの枝のように成形したもの。
sen.e: It is made in the same manner as Baishi to form into a peach branch shape.
It is made in the same manner as Baishi to form into a peach branch shape.
It is made in the same manner as Baishi to form into a peach branch shape.

sen.j: かっこ（「かっ」は食に渇の旁を合わせた字、「こ」は餬）
sen.e: Kakko
sen.cmt: 括弧内は漢字表記の説明のため、翻訳を省略しています。
sen.e: Kakko
Kakko

sen.j: 小麦粉をこねて蝎虫（サソリないしキクイムシとされる）の形とし、焼くか蒸したもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour to form into a 蝎虫 (considered as a scorpion or gribble) shape, and steaming or baking it.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to form into a 蝎虫 (considered as a scorpion or gribble) shape, and steaming or baking it.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to form into a 蝎虫 (considered as a scorpion or gribble) shape, and steaming or baking it.

sen.j: かっぺい（「ぺい」は餅）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called Kappei.
sen.cmt: 括弧内は漢字表記の説明のため、翻訳を省略しています。
sen.e: It is also called Kappei.
It is also called Kappei.

sen.j: 桂心（けいしん）
sen.e: Keishin
Keishin
Keishin

sen.j: 不明。
sen.e: It is unknown in detail.
It is unknown in detail.
It is unknown in detail.

sen.j: モチ米の粉にシナモンを混ぜて水で練り、ゆでて法冠のように成形し、油で揚げたものとも。
sen.e: It is said to be made by kneading glutinous rice flour that is mixed with cinnamon with water, boiling to form into a biretta shape, and then frying in oil.
It is said to be made by kneading glutinous rice flour mixed with cinnamon with water, boiling it to form into a biretta shape, and then frying it in oil.
sen.cmt: that is削除、boiling it、frying itとしました。
sen.e: It is said to be made by kneading glutinous rice flour mixed with cinnamon with water, boiling it to form into a biretta shape, and then frying it in oil.

sen.j: 黏臍（でんせい）
sen.e: Densei
Densei
Densei

sen.j: 小麦粉をこねてくぼみをつけてへそに似せ、油で揚げたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour to have a recess into a navel shape, and frying in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to have a recess into a navel shape, and frying it in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to have a recess into a navel shape, and frying it in oil.

sen.j: ひちら（「ひち」は食と畢、「ら」は食と羅を合わせた字）
sen.e: Hichira
sen.cmt: 括弧内は漢字表記の説明のため、翻訳を省略しています。
sen.e: Hichira
Hichira

sen.j: 米、アワ、キビなどの粉を薄く成形して焼いた、煎餅のようなもの。
sen.e: It is like rice cracker that is made by forming power such as rice, foxtail millet, a millet to be thin, and baking it.
It is like a rice cracker that is made by forming power such as rice, foxtail millet, millet to be thin, and baking it.
sen.cmt: rice cracker→a rice cracker、a millet→milletとしました。
sen.e: It is like a rice cracker that is made by forming power such as rice, foxtail millet, millet to be thin, and baking it.

sen.j: 鎚子（ついし）
sen.e: Tsuishi
Tsuishi
Tsuishi

sen.j: 米の粉を弾丸状に丸めて煮たもの。
sen.e: It is made by rounding powder of rice into a bullet shape, and then boiling it.
It is made by rounding powder of rice into a bullet shape, and then boiling it.
It is made by rounding powder of rice into a bullet shape, and then boiling it.

sen.j: 歓喜団（かんぎだん）
sen.e: Kankidan
Kankidan
Kankidan

sen.j: リョクトウ、米の粉、蒸し餅、ケシ、乾燥レンゲなどを練ってゆでたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading such as mung beans, powder of rice, steamed rice, a poppy, and a dry lotus flower, and the boiling it.
It is made by kneading such as mung beans, powder of rice, steamed rice, a poppy, and a dry lotus flower, and then boiling it.
It is made by kneading such as mung beans, powder of rice, steamed rice, a poppy, and a dry lotus flower, and then boiling it.

sen.j: 団喜（だんき）とも呼ぶ。
sen.e: It is also called Danki.
It is also called Danki.
It is also called Danki.

sen.j: 現存する清浄歓喜団は、小麦粉の生地で小豆餡を茶巾状に包み胡麻油で揚げたものとなっている。
sen.e: Current Seijyokankidan is made by wrapping azuki bean paste in the dough of wheat flour into a chakin (a cloth used in the tea ceremony) shape, and then frying in sesame oil.
Current Seijokankidan is made by wrapping azuki bean paste in the dough of wheat flour into a chakin (a cloth used in the tea ceremony) shape, and then frying in sesame oil.
Current Seijokankidan is made by wrapping azuki bean paste in the dough of wheat flour into a chakin (a cloth used in the tea ceremony) shape, and then frying in sesame oil.

sen.j: 伏兎（ぶと）
sen.e: Buto
Buto
Buto

sen.j: 小麦粉をこね油で焼いた、ないし揚げたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour, and baking or frying in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour, and baking or frying it in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour, and baking or frying it in oil.

sen.j: 現存する「ぶと饅頭」は、伏兎の生地に卵などを入れたドーナツ風の生地で餡を包んだ、あんドーナツ風の菓子。
sen.e: Current "Buto manjyu" is a cake like a doughnut with bean paste that is made by wrapping bean paste with the doughnut-like dough of Buto mixed with the dough of Buto and egg.
Current 'Buto manju' is a cake like a doughnut with bean paste that is made by wrapping bean paste with the doughnut-like dough of Buto mixed with the dough of Buto and egg.
sen.cmt: Buto manjuとし、シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: Current 'Buto manju' is a cake like a doughnut with bean paste that is made by wrapping bean paste with the doughnut-like dough of Buto mixed with the dough of Buto and egg.

sen.j: おこしごめ
sen.e: Okoshigome
Okoshigome
Okoshigome

sen.j: 椿餅
sen.e: Tsubakimochi
Tsubakimochi
Tsubakimochi

sen.j: 現在の桜餅（関西風）に酷似しており、中国伝来ではなく日本起源とも
sen.e: It is closely similar to current Sakuramochi (Kansai style), and is said to be derived from Japan rather than transmitted from China.
It is closely similar to current Sakuramochi (Kansai style), and is said to be derived from Japan rather than from China.
It is closely similar to current Sakuramochi (Kansai style), and is said to be derived from Japan rather than from China.

sen.j: 餅餤（へいだん）
sen.e: Heidan
Heidan
Heidan

sen.j: ガチョウやカモの煮卵、野菜などを餅で包んだもの。
sen.e: It is made by wrapping a boiled egg such as a goose or duck seasoned in soy sauce, or vegetables in a rice cake.
It is made by wrapping a boiled egg such as a goose or duck seasoned in soy sauce, or vegetables in a rice cake.
It is made by wrapping a boiled egg such as a goose or duck seasoned in soy sauce, or vegetables in a rice cake.

sen.j: 藤原行成が清少納言に贈ったと『枕草子』に記述がある。
sen.e: "Makura no soshi" has a description that FUJIWARA no Yukinari gave it to Seishonagon.
"Makura no Soshi" (The Pillow Book) has a description that FUJIWARA no Yukinari gave it to Seishonagon.
sen.cmt: "Makura no Soshi"とし補足追加 (用語集参照)
sen.e: "Makura no Soshi" (The Pillow Book) has a description that FUJIWARA no Yukinari gave it to Seishonagon.

sen.j: 結果（けっか）
sen.e: Kekka
Kekka
Kekka

sen.j: 小麦粉を練って緒のように結び、油で揚げたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour, knotting like a cord, and frying in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour, knotting it like a cord, and frying it in oil.
sen.cmt: knotting it, frying itとしました。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour, knotting it like a cord, and frying it in oil.

sen.j: 加久縄（かくのあわ）とも。
sen.e: It is also called "Kakunoawa."
It is also called "Kakunoawa."
It is also called "Kakunoawa."

sen.j: 索餅（さくべい）
sen.e: Sakubei
Sakubei
Sakubei

sen.j: 小麦粉を練って茹でたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour, and boiling.
It is made by kneading wheat flour, and boiling it.
It is made by kneading wheat flour, and boiling it.

sen.j: 現在のうどんやそうめんの原型といわれる。
sen.e: It is said a model of current udon and fine white noodles.
This is said to be a model of current udon and fine white noodles.
sen.cmt: It is said a model→This is said to be a modelとしました。
sen.e: This is said to be a model of current udon and fine white noodles.

sen.j: 煎餅
sen.e: Senbei
Senbei
Senbei

sen.j: 小麦粉や米の粉をこねて薄く成形し、油で焼いたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour or rice power to be thin, and baking it with oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour or rice flour to be thin, and baking it with oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour or rice flour to be thin, and baking it with oil.

sen.j: 現在の煎餅のもと。
sen.e: It is the origin of a current rice cracker.
It is the origin of a current rice cracker.
It is the origin of a current rice cracker.

sen.j: まがり（米部に環の旁を合わせた字）
sen.e: Magari

sen.e: Magari
Magari

sen.j: 小麦粉をこねて成形し、油で揚げたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour to perform formation, and then frying in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to perform formation, and then frying in oil.
It is made by kneading wheat flour-based dough into the appropriate shape, and then frying it in oil.

sen.j: 餺飥（はくたく）
sen.e: Hakutaku
Hakutaku
Hakutaku

sen.j: ほうとうとも読む。
sen.e: It is also called Hoto.
It is also called Hoto.
It is also called Hoto.

sen.j: 小麦粉をこねて平らにし、切り揃えたもの。
sen.e: It is made by kneading wheat flour to be flat, and then cutting it in the same size.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to be flat, and then cutting it in the same size.
It is made by kneading wheat flour to be flat, and then cutting it in the same size.

sen.j: 平安時代後期には、藤氏長者が春日大社で必ず食べた。
sen.e: Toshi choja ate it inevitably in the late Heian period.
Toshi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan) always ate it at Kasuga-taisha Shrine in the late Heian period.
sen.cmt: 「春日大社で」→訳漏れののため訳出、Toshi chojaの補足追加 (用語集参照)、inevitably→alwaysとし、位置を移動
sen.e: Toshi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan) always ate it at Kasuga-taisha Shrine in the late Heian period.

sen.j: 粉熟（ふずく）
sen.e: Fuzuku
Fuzuku (粉熟)
sen.cmt: 次行の内容より漢字表記追加
sen.e: Fuzuku (粉熟)

sen.j: 粉粥とも書く。
sen.e: It is also written "粉粥" in Japanese.
It is also written "粉粥" in kanji (Chinese characters).
sen.cmt: in Japanese→in kanji (Chinese characters)としました。
sen.e: It is also written "粉粥" in kanji (Chinese characters).

sen.j: 米、ムギ、ダイズ、アズキ、ゴマを粉にしてこねる。
sen.e: It is made by powdering rice, wheat, soy beans, adzuki beans, and sesame, kneading it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳分例外対処
sen.e: To make this, grind rice, wheat, soy beans, azuki beans, sesame into powder, and knead it.
sen.cmt: 前出の表記と統一するため、adzuki→azukiとし、一部訳直しました。
sen.e: To make this, grind rice, wheat, soy beans, azuki beans, sesame into powder, and knead it.

sen.j: それをゆでて甘葛をかけて竹に詰め、押し出して切ったもの。
sen.e: Thereafter, it is boiling, pouring amazura, and packing it into a bamboo, pushing it out and cutting it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳分例外対処
sen.e: Thereafter, boil it, pour amazura (traditional sweetner commonly used in the past) over it, pack it into a bamboo, push it out and cut it.
sen.cmt: it is削除、動詞のing削除、boil itとし、amazuraの補足追加、over it追加、and削除
sen.e: Thereafter, boil it, pour amazura (traditional sweetner commonly used in the past) over it, pack it into a bamboo, push it out and cut it.
